head.title: Climate Lessons, Right From the Mountaintop

hedline.hl1: Climate Lessons, Right From the Mountaintop

abstract.p: Dr Paul R Epstein letter on Oliver Morton's Nov 17 article questions value of desperate measure to save Mount Kilimanjaro's glaciers, noting warming problem is global; drawing

block.p: Taking a page from Christo, the artist famous for draping large structures, Oliver Morton (''The Tarps of Kilimanjaro,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 17) proposes capping Mount Kilimanjaro's glaciers with plastic to stanch the melting. But mountain glaciers are disappearing the world over, plants and mosquitoes are migrating upward, and the level of ''permanently'' frozen ground -- the ''freezing isotherm'' -- is 450 feet higher than it was in 1970.

Taking a page from Christo, the artist famous for draping large structures, Oliver Morton (''The Tarps of Kilimanjaro,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 17) proposes capping Mount Kilimanjaro's glaciers with plastic to stanch the melting. But mountain glaciers are disappearing the world over, plants and mosquitoes are migrating upward, and the level of ''permanently'' frozen ground -- the ''freezing isotherm'' -- is 450 feet higher than it was in 1970.
Mountain glaciers have reflected sunlight to help stabilize climate for 10,000 years, and they slowly release water that nourishes nature and human populations.

Today, melting ice cover and warming oceans are speeding up Earth's water cycle, leading to wide weather swings. Desperate Band-Aids in the face of such climate instability are, at best, temporary; at worst, pure folly.
PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D. Boston, Nov. 18, 2003
The writer is associate director, Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.
